L. No. 117-169, was enacted in August 2022. The IRA made the single largest investment in climate and energy in American history. The IRA will help the United States tackle the climate crisis, advance environmental justice, and secure our Nation s position as a world leader in domestic clean energy manufacturing. This law puts the United States on a pathway to achieving the Administration s climate goals, including a net zero operational emissions federal building portfolio by 2045, and net zero emissions procurement by 2050. Statutory Text Public Law No. 117-169, 136 Stat. 1818 (Aug. 16, 2022) SEC. 60502. ASSISTANCE FOR FEDERAL BUILDINGS. In addition to amounts otherwise available, there is appropriated for fiscal year 2022, out of any money in the Treasury not otherwise appropriated, $250,000,000, to remain available until September 30, 2031, to be deposited in the Federal Buildings Fund established under section 592 of title 40, United States Code, for measures necessary to convert facilities of the Administrator of General Services to high-performance green buildings (as defined in section 401 of the Energy Independence and Security Act of 2007 (42 U.S.C. 17061)). SEC. 60503. USE OF LOW-CARBON MATERIALS. (a) APPROPRIATION. In addition to amounts otherwise available, there is appropriated for fiscal year 2022, out of any money in the Treasury not otherwise appropriated, $2,150,000,000, to remain available until September 30, 2026, to be deposited in the Federal Buildings Fund established under section 592 of title 40, United States Code, to acquire and install materials and products for use in the construction or alteration of buildings under the jurisdiction, custody, and control of the General Services Administration that have substantially lower levels of embodied greenhouse gas emissions associated with all relevant stages of production, use, and disposal as compared to estimated industry averages of similar materials or products, as determined by the Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency. (b) DEFINITION OF GREENHOUSE GAS. In this section, the term  greenhouse gas  means the air pollutants carbon dioxide, hydrofluorocarbons, methane, nitrous oxide, perfluorocarbons, and sulfur hexafluoride. SEC. 60504. GENERAL SERVICES ADMINISTRATION EMERGING TECHNOLOGIES. In addition to amounts otherwise available, there is appropriated to the Administrator of General Services for fiscal year 2022, out of any money in the Treasury not otherwise appropriated, $975,000,000, to remain available until September 30, 2026, to be deposited in the Federal Buildings Fund established under section 592 of title 40, United States Code, for emerging and sustainable technologies, and related sustainability and environmental programs. Approach To Low Embodied Carbon Material Internal GSA Use Only - Page 4 As indicated above, IRA Section 60503 provides GSA with $2.15 billion for acquisition and installation of construction materials and products with substantially lower levels of embodied greenhouse gas emissions as compared to estimated industry averages, as determined by the Administrator of the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA). In December 2022, EPA issued an Interim Determination which provided GSA with guidance on how to identify clean building materials. Consistent with standard GSA practice and the Federal Acquisition Regulation, and taking extensive industry feedback into consideration, GSA issued IRA Low Embodied Carbon (LEC) asphalt, concrete (and cement), glass and steel materials requirements for use in acquiring compliant materials. In addition to these materials, the requirements apply to certain product assemblies if at least 80% of the assembly s total cost or total weight comprises materials that meet the LEC Requirements. In addition to acquiring and installing LEC materials, GSA needs to acquire and install high- performance green building measures and emerging and sustainable technologies. To accomplish this end, GSA needs to generate implementing solicitations and contract documents. This Desk Guide provides guidance instructing Contracting Officers and PBS Project Teams (i.e., Project Executives, Project Managers, Architect/Engineers, and Construction Managers) on incorporating IRA-funded work into required solicitations and agreements.1 This guidance supplements, and does not eliminate, other generally applicable procurement requirements (e.g., competition requirements and the Buy American and Trade Agreement Acts). Questions Questions regarding this guidance can be directed to pbsoampolicy@gsa.gov. The Office of Acquisition Management s OAM IRA Toolkit on GSA s National Acquisition Resource Center contains the most up-to-date IRA acquisition information, guidance, and tools. Questions regarding the overall IRA Program can be directed to IRA Program Questions Google Form, or directly to John.Dennis@gsa.gov. IRA Program Resources can also be found at: Inflation Reduction Act Program. Instructions for Solicitation of Construction Projects Involving IRA Funding Synopses, Solicitations, Agreements, Statements of Work and Specifications involving IRA funding must reflect a number of new elements. Specific requirements will depend on which IRA fund sources will be used: high performance green building funding, low embodied 1 Although construction solicitations and contracts are the principal focus of the Desk Guide, design and construction management requirements are also covered below. Internal GSA Use Only - Page 5 carbon construction material funding and/or emerging and sustainable technology funding.   Contracting Officers and PBS Project Teams responsible for procurements involving IRA funding must tailor procurement documents, including PBS Construction Template Solicitations and Agreements, as discussed below. Note: Contracting officers may not need all of the below language for a given project; for example, a project not involving LEC materials will not require LEC-specific evaluation factors and contract clauses, etc.   For projects utilizing indefinite delivery/indefinite quantity (IDIQ) vehicles, the substance of the below guidance should be addressed and incorporated to the extent practicable.   For noncompetitive projects (e.g., 8(a) sole source), the substance of the below guidance should be addressed and incorporated to the extent practicable. In lieu of a LEC evaluation factor, see  Noncompetitive Proposal Evaluation Requirements  section.   Blue text indicates passages required for insertion into operative procurement documents. This coloring should be changed to black once transferred to procurement documents.   Appendix A - IRA LEC Project Checklist contains a step-by-step checklist of solicitation and contract activities for LEC construction work covered by this guidance. I. Pre-Solicitation Requirements for Projects Requiring LEC Construction Materials In publicizing a Synopsis for a Proposed LEC Project Contract Action, Contracting Officers should include prominently-displayed synopsis language as follows. (Note: This section is not applicable to projects utilizing IDIQ vehicles.) In addition to the construction opportunity reflected herein, GSA is seeking suppliers and manufacturers that are interested in supplying low embodied carbon asphalt, concrete (and cement), glass and steel materials for the project. Suppliers and manufacturers of materials meeting GSA s Inflation Reduction Act Low Embodied Carbon asphalt, concrete (and cement), glass and steel requirements may submit an Expression of Interest to the contact below no later than <<CO to insert date>>. Expressions of Interest should indicate materials available and global warming potential values reflected in materials  environmental product declarations. Submission of an expression of interest grants GSA your permission to publish your firm s contact information and offerings for use by potential offerors on GSA construction requirements. Supplier and manufacturer contact information will be published in an informational amendment issued by GSA and, potentially, in other fora. By participating in the competition, offerors consent to unrestricted GSA use of supplier names and the GWP values associated with supplier materials. Such information may be disclosed publicly or used to inform other low embodied carbon procurement Internal GSA Use Only - Page 6 activities. Technical solutions, supplier pricing, and supplier-offeror terms and conditions will not be shared. Any objection shall be transmitted to the Contracting Officer by the due date for offers and shall adhere to 41 C.F.R.   105-60.601. As indicated by the text above, Contracting Officers shall collect, summarize, and provide contact information, available materials, and global warming potential values from Expressions of Interest as an informational amendment to the solicitation. This document shall include the following statement: Market research resources for identifying qualifying materials may include, but are not limited to, ASTM International s EPD Page, Building Transparency s Embodied Carbon in Construction Calculator (EC3), ICC Evaluation Service s EPD Directory, EPD International AB s EPD Library, the National Asphalt Paving Association s Emerald Eco- Label EPD Tool, the National Ready Mixed Concrete Association s Concrete EPDs page, NSF's Search for EPDs tool, and UL s SPOT product catalog and the Builtcold website. Note: The information provided herein is for informational purposes only and does not indicate or imply Federal endorsement of any organization, business, material or product. The Government makes no representation or warranty concerning the quality, performance, availability or suitability of any organization, business, material or product. II. Solicitation Requirements A. Notification of Use of IRA Funds The Solicitation shall be amended by adding the below text to the cover page or similarly prominent location in the front of the Solicitation: Note: The Inflation Reduction Act of 2022 (IRA), Pub. L. No. 117-169, enacted in August 2022, provided GSA with significant funding for (a) measures necessary to convert facilities to high-performance green buildings, (b) acquisition and installation of construction materials and products with substantially lower levels of embodied greenhouse gas emissions, and (c) emerging and sustainable technologies. The Contract resulting from this Solicitation will be funded in part by IRA appropriations, and it contains numerous IRA-specific requirements. Requirements include, but are not limited to, requirements regarding pricing, invoicing, submittals, materials, and construction. Offerors shall carefully review this Solicitation, the Agreement, the Statement of Work, the Specifications, and the Drawings. Offerors are responsible for accurately pricing and, if successful, fully performing all Contract requirements. Internal GSA Use Only - Page 7 If the contract will be funded in whole or in part with GSA s IRA LEC appropriation and will be procured on a competitive basis, add this sentence before the final sentence of the above passage: In addition, please note that this Solicitation contains an evaluation factor favoring certain construction materials with the lowest possible levels of embodied carbon. B. Pricing Instructions The Solicitation s Price Proposal instructions shall be amended by adding the below text to the Construction Solicitation Template s (e.g., DB201A, C201, CMc201, DB201-2) Additional Proposal Requirements narrative (typically Section II.C.4): GSA is required to track spending for each of the three appropriations it received under the Inflation Reduction Act of 2022 (IRA) -- for low-embodied carbon (LEC) materials, emerging and sustainable technologies, and high-performance green building measures -- and has established  budget activities  for each of these appropriations. A contract line item number (CLIN) for each of these budget activities has been included in the Agreement as necessary. In addition, subCLINs will be used to track spending on each of the LEC materials designated for IRA funding -- asphalt, concrete, glass, and steel. Offerors must include separate prices for IRA work under the corresponding IRA CLINs and subCLINs. Amounts for each IRA CLIN should reflect all expenses necessary to accomplish acquisition and installation of IRA work elements. A list of possible expenses follows below; this list is not exhaustive.   Expenses of acquiring and transporting products and materials required for IRA- funded work to the construction site;   Labor, general and administrative expenses, and overhead and profit reasonably attributable to installation of IRA-funded work;   Expenses for materials, tools, riggings and equipment (including safety equipment) required to install IRA-funded work;   Design, submittal and documentation expenses reasonably attributable to IRA- funded work;   Demolition and disposal expenses reasonably necessary for and attributable to IRA-funded work   Expenses necessary to return space to its condition preceding IRA-funded work;   Environmental remediation expenses required in execution of IRA-funded work; and   Phasing and commissioning expenses reasonably attributable to IRA-funded work. Internal GSA Use Only - Page 8 Note: In consultation with assigned OGC Counsel, Contracting Officers and PBS Project Teams should consider adding additional detail on specific necessary expenses associated with the project. C. Best Value Tradeoff The Solicitation s Method of Award shall be amended by adding the below text to the Construction Solicitation Template s (e.g., DB201A, C201, CMc201, DB201-2) Evaluation of Offers narrative (typically Section VI.A.2): Non-Price Factors, when combined, are significantly more important than Total Evaluated Price. D. Technical Evaluation Factor for Projects Requiring LEC Construction Materials GSA s IRA LEC asphalt, concrete (and cement), glass and steel requirements establish numeric global warming potential (GWP) limits for each of the EPA-approved construction material categories: concrete (and cement), asphalt, steel, and glass (IRA-Eligible Materials). For each material, GWP limits have been established for the best performing 20% of materials in terms of embodied carbon (Top 20% Limits), the best performing 40% of materials in terms of embodied carbon (Top 40% Limits), and better than industry average (Better Than Average Limit). When procuring construction projects requiring concrete (and cement), asphalt, steel and/or glass, Contracting Officers will utilize a technical evaluation factor that favors provision of IRA- Eligible Materials with the lowest possible GWP. Instructional language and an evaluation factor template are provided below. For an example of how to establish the table and calculate the offeror s score, please refer to the IRA Solicitation Sustainability Evaluation Factor Example slides. Key Considerations:   Contracting Officers shall work with PBS Project Teams to remove any IRA-Eligible Material present in the below evaluation factor that is inapplicable to the project s anticipated material needs.   Contracting Officers shall work with PBS Project Teams to develop LEC Material Evaluation Weights for individual materials to reflect the relative approximate cost of the materials required for the project. LEC Material Evaluation Weights must add up to 100%.   Separately, the Overall Weight of the factor relative to other factors (e.g., Past Performance, Prior Experience) shall be at least 15%.   Contracting Officers shall utilize the IRA Sustainability Factor Table in solicitations, which provides Offeror Instructions, a table with all materials and built-in calculations, and an example of a completed table. Internal GSA Use Only - Page 9   Depending on market research, certain IRA-Eligible Materials may be required to meet Top 20% Limits (see Market Research and Top 20% Materials, below). Market Research and Top 20% Materials Where market research indicates, and the CIPMO confirms, that certain IRA-Eligible Materials with GWP values at or better than Top 20% Limits are or should be available for a project, Contracting Officers shall substitute the following language for the first paragraph under Technical Acceptability, below: Offerors will only meet the standard for technical acceptability under this Factor if (1) they commit to furnish IRA-Eligible [INSERT CATEGORIES OF IRA-ELIGIBLE MATERIALS THAT MUST MEET TOP 20% LIMITS] with a GWP better (lower) than such materials  Top 20% Limits; and (2) they commit to furnish all other required IRA- Eligible Materials with a GWP better (lower) than each IRA-Eligible Material s Better Than Average Limit. NOTE: Where potential offerors indicate that such IRA-Eligible Materials meeting Top 20% Limits are NOT available and, based on the Contracting Officer s and CIPMO s review, these indications appear well founded, the Contracting Officer may consider issuing a solicitation amendment relaxing the Top 20% Limit requirements for those materials, permitting submission of materials meeting Top 40% Limits or Better than Average Limits. Evaluation Factor The Construction Solicitation Template s (e.g., DB201A, C201, CMc201, DB201-2) Technical Proposal narrative (typically Section II.D) shall be amended by adding the below evaluation factor (Note: For two-step Design/Build procurements, this factor should be utilized in Phase 2). Evaluation Factor # ___: Sustainability Background and Overview This project is funded in part by Section 60503 of the Inflation Reduction Act of 2022 (IRA), which provides funding for purchase of construction materials with substantially lower levels of embodied greenhouse gas emissions. GSA s IRA Low Embodied Carbon asphalt, concrete (and cement), glass and steel requirements establish numeric global warming potential (GWP) limits for certain EPA- approved construction materials: concrete (and cement), asphalt, steel, and glass (IRA- Eligible Materials). For each material, GWP limits have been established for the best performing 20% of materials in terms of embodied carbon (Top 20% Limits), the best performing 40% of materials in terms of embodied carbon (Top 40% Limits), and better than industry average (Better Than Average Limit). Internal GSA Use Only - Page 10 This Evaluation Factor calls for Offeror commitments to furnishing IRA-Eligible Materials with the lowest possible GWP values. IRA Limit Commitments proposed under this evaluation factor will be incorporated into the successful offeror s resultant contract. Individual materials  GWP values may be found on individual manufacturers  environmental product declarations (EPDs) (see the sam.gov presolicitation notice for some publicly-available tools that may help identify potential suppliers). EPDs must meet the standards reflected in GSA s IRA Low Embodied Carbon asphalt, concrete (and cement), glass and steel requirements (see Compliance Documentation criteria listed for each IRA-Eligible Material). Technical Acceptability Offerors will only meet the standard for technical acceptability under this Factor if they commit to furnish all required IRA-Eligible Materials with a GWP better (lower) than each IRA-Eligible Material s Better Than Average Limit. Scoring Offerors meeting the standard for technical acceptability, above, will receive a number of Raw Scores, one for each IRA-Eligible Material required by the Contract:   Offerors will receive a Raw Score of 90 for each IRA-Eligible Material commitment that is better (lower) than GSA s Top 20% Limits.   Offerors will receive a Raw Score of 40 for each IRA-Eligible Material commitment that is only better (lower) than GSA s Top 40% Limits.   Offerors will receive a Raw Score of 20 for each IRA-Eligible Material commitment that is only better (lower) than GSA s Better Than Average Limit. Offerors shall complete the  IRA Sustainability Factor Table  attached to this solicitation by filling out the applicable IRA Limit they commit to meet for each IRA- Eligible Material. Based upon the offeror s selection in the  IRA Limit Commitment  column, the associated Raw Score, a Preliminary Weighted Score, and the Preliminary Total Weighted Score will be automatically calculated. In addition, for each IRA-Eligible Material identified in the IRA Sustainability Factor Table, offerors shall submit EPDs listing that material s GWP. Such EPDs must meet the standards reflected in GSA s IRA Low Embodied Carbon asphalt, concrete (and cement), glass and steel requirements (see Compliance Documentation criteria listed for each IRA-Eligible Material). Raw Score Supplement Offerors will receive a supplemental 10 points on Raw Scores for each IRA-Eligible Material where the material s submitted EPD reflects the lowest GWP value received in the competition for that material. For instance, where two offerors propose materials meeting the Top 20% Limit for glass, and Offeror A submits a glass EPD reflecting a Internal GSA Use Only - Page 11 GWP value lower than that reflected in Offeror B s glass EPD, Offeror A and B will receive raw scores of 100 and 90 for that material, respectively. During evaluations, the Government will add Raw Score Supplements, if any, to offeror s Preliminary Weighted Scores to calculate Final Weighted Scores. In the event of a tie for lowest-GWP values for a given material, those tied offerors will all receive the Raw Score Supplement for that material. Note 1: By submitting an offer, Offeror consents to unrestricted GSA use of supplier names and the GWP values associated with supplier materials. Such information may be disclosed publicly or used to inform other low embodied carbon procurement activities. Technical solutions, supplier pricing and supplier-offeror terms and conditions will not be shared. Any objection shall be transmitted to the Contracting Officer by the due date for offers and shall adhere to 41 C.F.R.   105-60.601. Note 2: For each offeror that is unable to submit any of the compliant EPDs by the proposal due date, the offeror shall submit a statement for each such missing compliant EPD (a) certifying that it is unable to submit a compliant EPD by the proposal due date, and (b) promising to submit a compliant EPD within 120 days from the contract award ((a) and (b) collectively constituting an  EPD Pledge ). Failure by an offeror to submit either a compliant EPD or an EPD Pledge (as described in the immediately preceding sentence) for each IRA-Eligible Material listed in the IRA Sustainability Factor Table by the proposal due date shall result in the offeror s proposal being unacceptable. Offerors submitting an EPD Pledge in lieu of a compliant EPD for a given IRA-Eligible Material will not be eligible for a Raw Score Supplement for that material, as described above. Any awardee that submitted an EPD Pledge in lieu of a compliant EPD for a given IRA- Eligible Material will still be bound by IRA Limit Commitments made in their IRA Sustainability Factor Table. Note as well that the contract resulting from this solicitation shall have the following provision:  Within 120 days after contract award, the Contractor shall submit a compliant EPD for any IRA-Eligible Material for which the Contractor was unable to submit a compliant EPD by the proposal due date (if any). Such EPD must reflect GWP values that comply with the IRA Limit Commitments incorporated into the contract. GSA shall not issue a Notice to Proceed with construction services to the Contractor until the Contractor has submitted a compliant EPD for each IRA-Eligible Material for which the Contractor was unable to submit a compliant EPD by the proposal due date.  The Construction Solicitation Template s (e.g., DB201A, C201, CMc201, DB201-2) Non-Price Factors text (typically Section VI.F.) shall be amended by adding the below evaluation factor, tailored as indicated (Weight shall be at least 15%): Evaluation Factor # ___: Sustainability Weight [INSERT (see above)]% Internal GSA Use Only - Page 12 (1) The Sustainability Factor will be scored as outlined in Section [INSERT], above. (2) GSA will verify Offeror s scoring and that IRA Limits are supported by environmental product declarations (EPDs) from proposed suppliers. (3) GSA will verify that Offeror s EPDs adhere to EPD standards reflected in GSA s IRA Low Embodied Carbon asphalt, concrete (and cement), glass and steel requirements (see Compliance Documentation criteria listed for each IRA-Eligible Material). (4) GSA will make any scoring adjustments necessary to correct patent errors. Once GSA has verified the Offeror s scoring and, if necessary, made any corrections, the overall weighted score will be assigned an adjectival rating, as follows: [CO to tailor based on adjectival ratings utilized in the Source Selection Plan] Weighted Score Adjectival Rating 100 points Exceptional 90-99 points Very Good 20-89 points Acceptable Unacceptable Unacceptable Note 1: Any proposal that does not meet the standard for Technical Acceptability will be rated as  Unacceptable  under this factor and will be ineligible for award. Note 2: Any proposal that furnishes all required IRA-Eligible Material with a GWP better (lower) than GSA s Top 20% Limits will receive a Total Weighted Score of 90 points (Exceptional), with Raw Score Supplements potentially increasing the Total Weighted Score to 100 points. Note 3: If an EPD is not available, GSA will review the offeror s EPD Pledge. E. Noncompetitive Proposal Evaluation Requirements for Projects Requiring LEC Construction Materials GSA s IRA Low Embodied Carbon asphalt, concrete (and cement), glass and steel requirements establish numeric global warming potential (GWP) limits for each of the EPA- approved construction material categories: concrete (and cement), asphalt, steel, and glass (IRA-Eligible Materials). For each material, GWP limits have been established for the best performing 20% of materials in terms of embodied carbon (Top 20% Limits), the best performing Internal GSA Use Only - Page 13 40% of materials in terms of embodied carbon (Top 40% Limits), and better than industry average (Better Than Average Limit). When procuring construction projects requiring concrete (and cement), asphalt, steel and/or glass, Contracting Officers will request that the offeror provide a proposal that favors provision of IRA-Eligible Materials with the lowest possible GWP. Depending on market research, certain IRA-Eligible Materials may be required to meet Top 20% Limits (see Market Research and Top 20% Materials, below). Instructional language and proposal requirement language are provided below. Contracting Officers shall work with PBS Project Teams to remove any IRA-Eligible Material present in the below table that is inapplicable to the project s anticipated material needs. Market Research and Top 20% Materials Where market research indicates, and the CIPMO confirms, that certain IRA-Eligible Materials with GWP values at or better than Top 20% Limits are available for a project or will be available by the anticipated contract award date, Contracting Officers shall substitute the following language for the fifth paragraph of the blue LEC Commitment Proposal language, below: For IRA-Eligible [INSERT IRA-ELIGIBLE MATERIALS THAT MUST MEET TOP 20% LIMITS], materials MUST have embodied GWP values that are less than or equal to GSA s Top 20% Limits. For all other materials, the proposal shall provide IRA-Eligible construction materials with embodied GWP values that are less than or equal to the GSA IRA Top 20% Limits reflected in GSA s IRA LEC asphalt, concrete (and cement), glass and steel requirements. If Top 20% materials are not available, please propose materials with embodied GWP that are less than or equal to the GSA IRA Top 40% Limit for that material. If Top 40% materials are not available for those material categories, please propose materials with embodied GWP that are less than the Better Than Average Limit for that material. NOTE: Where potential offerors indicate that IRA-Eligible Materials meeting mandatory Top 20% Limits are not available and, based on the Contracting Officer s and CIPMO s review, these indications appear well-founded, the Contracting Officer may consider amending the solicitation to relax the Top 20% Limit requirements for those materials, permitting submission of materials meeting Top 40% Limits or Better than Average Limits. Additional Evaluation Factor Requirements for Projects Requiring LEC Construction Materials IRA LEC projects also require additional technical evaluation factor considerations. The below link outlines the requirements for (1) All construction projects (other than two-phase design/build Design Excellence projects) and (2) All two-phase design/build Design Excellence projects. This includes the inclusion of a Small Business participation evaluation factor, and for two- phase design/build Design Excellence projects, the adjusted weights of the Phase 2 Design Excellence evaluation factors, approved by the Office of the Chief Architect. IRA Source Selection Evaluation Factor Weights III. Agreement Requirements A. Price Form and Financial Guidance The Construction Agreement Template s (e.g., DB101, C101, CMc101) Contract Price Form (typically Section II.B) shall be amended to reflect the following CLIN and subCLIN structure in order to consistently track IRA obligations. Please review the IRA Supplemental EASi Guidance for instructions on creating a procurement request (PR), establishing CLINs, and processing invoices and receiving reports for IRA-funded projects. Additional PBS financial guidance can be found within the GSA Office of Budget s Inflation Reduction Act Financial Guidance. That document provides supplemental guidance regarding IRA funding-specific accounting codes, operating expenses, systems, and tracking. results.EO_Text: Federal Register Vol. 90, No. 17 Tuesday, January 28, 2025 Title 3  The President Presidential Documents 8233 Proclamation 10885 of January 20, 2025 Flying the Flag of the United States at Full-Staff on Inau- guration Day By the President of the United States of America A Proclamation By the authority vested in me by the Constitution and the laws of the United States of America, and in honor of Inauguration Day and everything good and noble that it represents about our Nation, our people, and our form of Government, I hereby order that, on this and all future Inauguration Days, the flag of the United States shall be flown at full-staff. Accordingly, I hereby order that the flag of the United States shall be flown at full-staff at the White House and upon all public buildings and grounds, at all military posts and naval stations, and on all naval vessels of the Federal Government, in the District of Columbia and throughout the United States and its Territories and possessions, for the remainder of this day beginning immediately. I also direct that, for the same period of time, the flag shall be flown at full-staff at all United States embassies, legations, consular offices, and other facilities abroad, including all military facilities and naval vessels and stations. Upon the end of this Inauguration Day, I hereby order that the flag of the United States shall be returned to half-staff as directed by Proclamation 10876 of December 29, 2024 (Announcing the Death of James Earl Carter, Jr.), in recognition of the memory of our former President, until the period of 30 days from the day of his death has concluded. - 0 D C O D S E R P h t i w D O R P 3 2 N R 0 2 1 K S D n o r e l l e h m u r d d VerDate Sep<11>2014 15:48 Jan 27, 2025 Jkt 265001 PO 00000 Frm 00001 Fmt 4705 Sfmt 4790 E:\FR\FM\28JAD0.SGM 28JAD0 8234 Federal Register / Vol. 90, No. 17 / Tuesday, January 28, 2025 / Presidential Documents IN WITNESS WHEREOF, I have hereunto set my hand this twentieth day of January, in the year of our Lord two thousand twenty-five, and of the Independence of the United States of America the two hundred and forty- ninth. results.Summary:
Here's a comprehensive analysis:

1. Policy Summary:
The document is the "Inflation Reduction Act of 2022 Construction Solicitation Desk Guide" detailing GSA's implementation guidelines for construction projects funded under the Inflation Reduction Act. It provides comprehensive instructions for solicitation, contract requirements, and sustainability efforts across three key areas: high-performance green buildings, low embodied carbon materials, and emerging sustainable technologies.

2. Executive Order Summary:
This is a presidential proclamation regarding the flying of the United States flag at full-staff on Inauguration Day. The order specifically directs flag protocol for the day of inauguration and subsequent actions related to half-staffing in memory of former President Jimmy Carter.

3. Applicability Analysis:
The executive order does NOT substantively impact the Inflation Reduction Act Construction Solicitation Desk Guide. The proclamation is purely a flag protocol document and contains no provisions that would alter GSA's procurement, construction, or sustainability policies.

The executive order:
- Relates to flag display protocols
- Concerns a specific day (Inauguration Day)
- Has no bearing on construction, procurement, or sustainability practices

4. Compliance Next Steps:
No compliance actions are required. The Inflation Reduction Act Construction Solicitation Desk Guide can continue to be implemented as originally drafted.

Recommendation: File this executive order in standard administrative documentation without requiring any policy modifications.
results.updated_summary: The executive order regarding flag display on Inauguration Day has no material relationship to GSA's Inflation Reduction Act Construction Solicitation guidelines, and therefore does not affect the existing policy framework.
results.phase1_response:
## Policy Impact Analysis

### 1. Policy Document Summary
The Inflation Reduction Act of 2022 Construction Solicitation Desk Guide is an internal GSA document that provides comprehensive guidance for construction projects involving IRA funding. The policy covers requirements for Low Embodied Carbon (LEC) construction materials, sustainability evaluation factors, solicitation procedures, technical specifications, and review processes. Key components include pre-solicitation requirements, evaluation criteria for sustainable materials, Environmental Product Declaration (EPD) requirements, and CIPMO review procedures for IRA-funded construction projects.

### 2. Executive Order Summary
Proclamation 10885 of January 20, 2025, is a ceremonial order directing that the American flag be flown at full-staff on Inauguration Day (January 20, 2025) and all future Inauguration Days. The order applies to the White House, all public buildings and grounds, military installations, naval facilities, and U.S. diplomatic facilities worldwide. After Inauguration Day ends, the flag returns to half-staff per the previous proclamation honoring former President Carter until the 30-day mourning period concludes.

### 3. Executive Order Applicability Analysis
This executive order does **not apply** to the IRA Construction Solicitation Desk Guide policy. The executive order is purely ceremonial in nature, addressing flag display protocols for a specific commemorative occasion. It contains no provisions that would affect:

- Construction project procedures or requirements
- Sustainability standards or LEC material specifications  
- Solicitation processes or evaluation criteria
- Environmental compliance requirements
- GSA's operational procedures for IRA-funded projects

The executive order operates in an entirely different policy domain (ceremonial protocols) than the construction guidance document (procurement and environmental standards). There is no substantive overlap between flag display requirements and construction project management procedures.

### 4. Next Steps for Compliance
No compliance actions are required because the executive order does not affect this policy. The IRA Construction Solicitation Desk Guide can continue to be implemented as written without any modifications related to this proclamation.

**Final Determination: [Not Affected]**

results.phase2_response:
Let me analyze this step by step:

**Step 1: Policy Domain/Subject Area**
The policy is the "IRA of 2022 Construction Solicitation Desk Guide" - this is a technical guidance document for federal construction projects under the Inflation Reduction Act of 2022. It covers procurement procedures, sustainability evaluation factors, construction materials requirements, and submittal forms for GSA construction solicitations.

**Step 2: Executive Order Domain/Subject Area**  
The executive order "Flying The Flag Of The United States At Full-Staff On Inauguration Day" (Proclamation 10885) addresses flag display protocols. It mandates that the U.S. flag be flown at full-staff on Inauguration Day at federal buildings, military installations, and naval vessels.

**Step 3: Domain Comparison and Impact Assessment**
These are entirely different domains:
- Policy: Federal construction procurement and sustainability requirements
- EO: Ceremonial flag display protocols

There is no direct operational intersection between construction solicitation procedures and flag display requirements. The EO does not modify procurement processes, environmental standards, or construction guidelines.

**Step 4: Independent Assessment**
While both involve federal facilities, the connection is purely coincidental. The construction desk guide governs how GSA manages building projects, while the EO governs symbolic flag display. The EO's flag requirements would apply to completed federal buildings regardless of how they were constructed or procured.

**Final Decision: [Not Affected]**

**Full Justification:**

1. **Policy Domain**: Federal construction procurement under the Inflation Reduction Act, focusing on sustainability requirements, technical evaluation factors, and solicitation procedures for GSA construction projects.

2. **Executive Order Domain**: Ceremonial flag display protocol requiring full-staff flag display on Inauguration Day at federal properties.

3. **Impact Analysis**: There is no direct or indirect impact. The EO addresses symbolic ceremonial requirements that are completely separate from construction procurement processes. The flag display mandate applies to operational facilities regardless of their construction method or procurement history.

4. **Supporting Language**: The EO specifically addresses "flying the flag" and "full-staff" requirements, while the policy focuses on "construction solicitation," "sustainability evaluation factors," and "LEC construction materials." These are distinct operational spheres with no overlap.

5. **Edge Cases Considered**: Even though both may apply to the same federal buildings, they govern entirely different aspects - one governs how buildings are built/procured, the other governs ceremonial flag display at completed facilities. This coincidental applicability to the same physical structures does not create policy relevance.

The initial Phase 1 flag of "Not Affected" is correct.
