results.Policy_Title: Infrastructure Investment and Jobs Act Financial Guidance
results.Policy_Filename_Text: 65 - Infrastructure Investment and Jobs Act Financial Guidance.pdf
results.Policy Text: U.S. General Services Administration September 28, 2022 MEMORANDUM FOR: PBS REGIONAL COMMISSIONERS; REGIONAL DESIGN AND CONSTRUCTION DIRECTORS; REGIONAL PORTFOLIO MANAGEMENT DIRECTORS; and ZONAL PBS FINANCIAL SERVICES DIRECTORS FROM: BRIAN BLOCK ACTING BUDGET DIRECTOR (BB) OFFICE OF BUDGET SUBJECT: Infrastructure Investment and Jobs Act Financial Guidance This memorandum provides supplemental financial execution guidance regarding the $3,418,008,000 appropriated to the Federal Buildings Fund (FBF) by the Infrastructure Investment and Jobs Act (IIJA), P.L. 117-58, 135 Stat. 429, 1382-1383. Throughout this memorandum, the IIJA will be referred to as the Bipartisan Infrastructure Law (BIL). Specifically, this memorandum establishes the following new tracking requirements in Section C:   Tracking of BIL program support costs using FBF Fund 192X:   Public Buildings Service (PBS) must use tracking code Y0000BIL in the accounting string for non-labor program requirements using 192X funding.   PBS shall begin timecarding administrative hours spent on BIL to HRLinks labor code Y0000BIL beginning 09/25/22 (pay period ending 10/8).   Does not apply to SES or Land Ports of Entry Program Management Office employees, or employees who can code time to an individual project or RWA. Future updates may be incorporated in subsequent memoranda should reporting requirements change or as other BIL execution requirements develop. If you have any questions regarding this guidance, please contact Nicole Diederich, Director OCFO, PBS Office of Budget unless otherwise noted. DocuSign Envelope ID: 7808D437-0B9B-42AF-9024-32EF79B4FA5A Contents A. Overview B. New Accounting Codes 1. Fund 192J 2. Budget Activities 3. Function Codes and SOCs C. Tracking PBS Operating Expenses Related to BIL 1. Travel 2. Labor Coding/Timecarding 3. All Other D. Requesting BIL Funds 1. Allowance Process E. Pegasys 1. Pegasys Templates 2. Purchase Cards (non-travel) 3. Reports 4. G&A Allocation 5. Cost Transfers F. Property 1. Establishing 192J Funded Projects 2. Monitoring Capitalized Projects G. RWA Tracking H. PBS Systems I. FY 2022 and Beyond 2 3 4 4 4 5 6 6 6 6 6 7 8 8 8 8 9 9 10 10 11 12 13 14 DocuSign Envelope ID: 7808D437-0B9B-42AF-9024-32EF79B4FA5A A. Overview The President signed the Infrastructure Investment and Jobs Act (IIJA), P.L. 117-58, 135 Stat. 429, on November 15, 2021 providing $3,418,008,000 to the U.S. General Services Administration for various work on border stations and land ports of entry. Throughout this document this act will be referred to as the Bipartisan Infrastructure Law (BIL). The relevant enacted language from the Act is as follows:  For an additional amount to be deposited in the  Federal Buildings Fund , $3,418,008,000, to remain available until expended, for construction and acquisition, and repairs and alterations of border stations and land ports of entry, of which no more than $250,000,000 shall be for Program Contingency and Operational Support for necessary expenses for projects funded under this heading, including, moving governmental agencies (including space alterations and adjustments, and telecommunications relocation expenses) in connection with the assignment, allocation and transfer of space, leasing of temporary space, and building operations, of which  (1) $2,527,808,000 shall be for projects on the U.S. Customs and Border Protection five-year plan; (2) $430,200,000 shall be for projects with completed U.S. Customs and Border Protection/General Services Administration feasibility studies as prioritized in the  American Jobs Plan Project List  submitted to the House and Senate Committees on Appropriations on May 28, 2021; and (3) $210,000,000 shall be for land ports of entry (LPOE) infrastructure paving; acquisition of leased LPOEs; and additional Federal Motor Carrier Safety Administration requirements at the Southern Border: Provided, That the General Services Administration shall submit a plan, by project, regarding the use of funds made available to the Administrator under this heading in this Act to the Committees on Appropriations of the House of Representatives and the Senate within 90 days of enactment of this Act: Provided further, That the Administrator of General Services shall notify the Committees on Appropriations of the House of Representatives and the Senate quarterly on the obligations and expenditures of the funds provided under this heading in this Act by account of the Federal Buildings Fund: Provided further, That funds made available under this heading in this Act for Federal Buildings Fund activities may be transferred to, and merged with, other accounts within the Federal Buildings Fund only to the extent necessary to meet program requirements for such activities: Provided further, That the General Services Administration will provide notice in advance to the Committees on Appropriations of the House of Representatives and the Senate of any proposed transfers: Provided further, That funds made available to the Administrator under this heading in this Act shall not be subject to section 3307 of title 40, United States Code: Provided further, That amounts made available under this heading in this Act shall be in addition to any other amounts made available for such purposes, including for construction and acquisition or repairs and alterations: Provided further, That such amount is designated by the Congress as being 3 DocuSign Envelope ID: 7808D437-0B9B-42AF-9024-32EF79B4FA5A for an emergency requirement pursuant to section 4112(a) of H. Con. Res. 71 (115th Congress), the concurrent resolution on the budget for fiscal year 2018, and to section 251(b) of the Balanced Budget and Emergency Deficit Control Act of 1985.  The Office of the Chief Financial Officer (OCFO) Office of Budget (BB), Financial Management (BG), and Office of PBS Financial Services (BR), together with the Public Buildings Service (PBS), drafted this guidance document for the management of the Federal Buildings Fund (FBF) BIL funds. B. New Accounting Codes 1. Fund 192J Fund 192J has been established in GSA s accounting system, Pegasys, for the use of PBS, and will be used specifically for the obligation of FBF funds appropriated by the BIL. The Treasury Account Symbol (TAS) for fund 192J is the same as the FBF; TAS 47X4542. Please note that the FBF, which is the traditional funding vehicle for PBS, is a no-year quasi-revolving fund and permits PBS to use new obligational authority until expended. As the enacted language states,  For an additional amount to be deposited in the  Federal Buildings Fund , $3,418,008,000, to remain available until expended .. , fund 192J will be structured as a no-year fund in Pegasys . BIL obligations and expenses must not be included in the regular FBF 192X account and reported as such, due to special reporting requirements stipulated for these funds under the Act and apportionment by the Office of Management and Budget (OMB). Therefore, for ease of reporting, the BIL funding must be tracked and managed separately, using a new fund (fund 192J). For financial reporting, all obligations and outlays will still be reported under the Federal Buildings Fund TAS 47X4542. 2. Budget Activities The BIL appropriated funds in five different spending categories. In order to track and manage each category within the spending plan and apportionment, five budget activities within 192J are created and listed below. These are established for use in fund 192J only, and cannot be used in fund 192X.   PG11 CBP LPOE Five Year Plan Projects: Land Ports of Entry (LPOE) projects on the U.S. Customs and Border Protection five-year plan.   PG12 AJP Priority LPOE Projects: projects with completed U.S. Customs and Border Protection/General Services Administration feasibility studies as prioritized in the  American Jobs Plan Project List  submitted to the House and Senate Committees on Appropriations on May 28, 2021. 4 DocuSign Envelope ID: 7808D437-0B9B-42AF-9024-32EF79B4FA5A   PG13 LPOE Paving, Acquisition of Leased LPOE, and FMCSA Projects: for LPOE infrastructure paving; acquisition of leased LPOEs; and additional Federal Motor Carrier Safety Administration (FMCSA) requirements at the Southern Border.   PG14 Program Contingency: This budget activity will be used for project contingency funds.   Per the public law:  no more than $250,000,000 shall be for Program Contingency and Operational Support for necessary expenses for projects funded under this heading, including, moving governmental agencies (including space alterations and adjustments, and telecommunications relocation expenses) in connection with the assignment allocation and transfer of space, leasing of temporary space, and building operations.    PG15 Operational Support: This budget activity will be used for operational support costs. This funding is capped at $250,000,000 along with the contingency.   Per the public law: no more than $250,000,000 shall be for Program Contingency and Operational Support for necessary expenses for projects funded under this heading, including, moving governmental agencies (including space alterations and adjustments, and telecommunications relocation expenses) in connection with the assignment allocation and transfer of space, leasing of temporary space, and building operations.   At this time, PBS does not plan to issue allowances for operational support from the BIL. Please see section C  Tracking PBS Operating Expenses Related to BIL . All current budget activities in fund 192X will continue to be used only for FBF activities as appropriated, and will not be available under fund 192J. Regular 192X and BIL 192J funding can be used in conjunction with each other on LPOE projects. These situations will be reviewed on a case-by-case basis in coordination with OCFO, PBS Portfolio, Office of the General Counsel, and the LPOE Program Management Office (PMO). The use of funds for PG11, PG12, PG13, PG14, and PG15 will be directly tied to the approved spending plan. The regions must adhere to the project list as provided in the spend plan. 3. Function Codes and SOCs The existing Function Codes and Sub-Object Classes (SOCs) for 192X will be used for fund 192J. Please apply accounting classification codes in accordance with normal coding guidelines depending on the purchase. Please refer to the PBS Standardized Coding website to find more information. 5 DocuSign Envelope ID: 7808D437-0B9B-42AF-9024-32EF79B4FA5A C. Tracking PBS Operating Expenses Related to BIL At this time, PBS does not plan to issue allowances for operational support from the BIL and all operating costs will be funded from regular FBF fund 192X. It is still necessary to track 192X costs related to executing the BIL projects. Tracking code Y0000BIL was set up in order to track BIL expenses paid for by regular 192X funding. 1. Travel At this time, all travel continues to be paid from 192X BA60. All travel in Concur for a BIL project need to cite the Y0000BIL tracking code. This code has been loaded in Concur for certain organization codes related to BIL. If the coding for your organization does not appear, please contact your Building Operations budget analyst. 2. Labor Coding/Timecarding Every PBS employee is to follow current business rules regarding timecarding their labor hours to function codes, buildings, projects, and reimbursable work authorizations (RWAs). Employees who work on BIL projects need to code their time to the specific projects as normal. Effective with the pay period beginning 9/25/22 (pay period ending 10/08), those who spend administrative time on BIL work need to code their time to Y0000BIL in HRLinks using the region s dummy building number. This does not apply to SES or PMO employees, or to PBS employees who can code time to individual projects or RWAs. Employees who work full time on BIL projects within the LPOE PMO do not need to timecard to the Y-code as their organization code is already delineated as full time BIL. Please see section E.4 for more information on General & Administrative (G&A) allocation. 3. All Other Management Support contract employees who are not working on a specific project must be coded to Sub Object Class H03 (Contract labor) with tracking code, Y0000BIL. The tracking code will enable GSA to separate out embedded contract employees from other types of contracts. The LPOE PMO must be notified of all new management support contracts supporting the BIL prior to award. All other costs not included in a project or in the BIL spend plan, but related to the BIL, such as training, will continue to use the Y0000BIL code for tracking in 192X. D. Requesting BIL Funds BIL funds will be managed by the PMO through internal tracking and spend planning. As regions prepare to make awards, regions should follow the standard allowance 6 DocuSign Envelope ID: 7808D437-0B9B-42AF-9024-32EF79B4FA5A request process, with BIL process clarifications below, to obtain the project funding in Pegasys. 1. Allowance Process For PG11-PG14, OCFO PBS Budget Division (BBP) will send instructions for regional project and budget teams to create line item project numbers in IRIS. The best practice is for regions to plan to request project allowances for each major project phase, including appropriate contingency, ensuring appropriate time before award, usually once contract awards are pending. The following procedural requirements for issuing allowances shall be followed:   All allowance request packets must be submitted to the allowance request mailbox (allowance.requests@gsa.gov).   The regional program office must coordinate with the zonal budget analyst to prepare the GSA form 3285 allowance request.   A completed GSA Form 3285 is required as an attachment to the allowance request email. The form must be filled out in its entirety to include all regional approving persons, the appropriation, and the amount that the region is requesting. Also, the description section must include which national spend plan the region is requesting funds from and the purpose for how the funds will be obligated. In addition to the GSA Form 3285, regions need to provide any applicable supporting documents to verify the actual award amount, such as, the contractor's proposal (i.e., Standard Form 1442), to support the allowance request.     Note: for all BIL studies (site acquisition, NEPA, pre-design) allowances, regions may provide the Independent Government Estimate as support.   The zonal budget office will then attach the GSA form 3285, supporting documents, spend plan and submit the funds request email to the Central Office allowance request mailbox (allowance.requests@gsa.gov).   Upon receiving the allowance request, BBP will review the allowance request and then forward the request for approval to the LPOE PMO and Office of Portfolio Management & Customer Engagement. Please allow a lead-time of approximately two days for the Central Office to review and concur.   After OCFO approvals have been obtained, BBP will complete the project allowance in Pegasys. After receiving notification that the allowance has been processed, the regional budget analyst must establish an operating plan (A5 level) in Pegasys.   The new PBS project management system, Kahua, will be automating the allowance creation and approval process. Once that feature is implemented, allowances will be created and routed in Kahua. 7 DocuSign Envelope ID: 7808D437-0B9B-42AF-9024-32EF79B4FA5A E. Pegasys 1. Pegasys Templates New Pegasys templates and budget activities have been added for fund 192J. Accounting templates for the below organization codes have been created for fund 192J. Templates for additional organization codes can be added as needed, please contact BBP with any questions or to request an organization code. Regional Org Codes available for 192J: An LPOE PMO has been established within Region 2. All PMO costs must be coded to organization code P02L0001. Pegasys accounting templates with the P02L0001 organization code have been created for 192X PG60, PG61 and 192J PG15. 2. Purchase Cards (non-travel) Purchase card users must log their BIL-related transactions into Pegasys using fund 192J, and must remember to perform a timely reconciliation. Any purchase must be in accordance with the approved BIL spend plan and directly supporting a BIL project. Regions must follow all current credit card processes; 192J is available in the credit card bot. 3. Reports The following is a list of Pegasys reports that have been created to include fund 192J financial activity. Business Intelligence (BI) databases will be updated to include transactions from 192J. These reports can be found directly in Pegasys or in BI. 8 DocuSign Envelope ID: 7808D437-0B9B-42AF-9024-32EF79B4FA5A   FR83AB   Allowance/Budget Plan Status Report   Trial Balance Report   Month-end Obligation Status Reports Income & Expense (I&E) Reports     Fixed Asset Trial Balance Report     ULO Database   Quarterly Commitments and Obligations Report for quarterly reporting to Inventory Status Report Congress (as requested in the act) Additionally, activity will be tracked on the below dashboard as updated by PBS and OCFO:   PMO Financial Tracking Report 4. General & Administration Allocation Fund 192J transactions that are coded without a building number, project number or RWA number will go into the various PBS G&A pools; the particular pool classification will depend on the distribution level of the organization code, just as with other Fund 192 indirect transactions. Likewise, fund 192J direct transactions against a particular building will factor into the distribution of the G&A pools just as with other Fund 192 direct transactions. All regions should evaluate the impact of 192J funding on their workloads when determining the new workload factors for FY23 and forward. As most 192J funding is anticipated to be related to capital projects, regions should pay special attention to the impact on the capitalization factors. The Pegasys cost allocation module and the I&E reports will include the 192J fund transactions in with the other Fund 192 transactions to produce one official set of regional and nationwide FBF I&E reports. For more information, please contact Stefanie Crane at 202-528-8178. 5. Cost Transfers Cost transfers occur after funds are expensed. Cost transfers often correct coding errors or reflect changes in coding decisions. They do not require approval by OMB or Congress, but may require explanation after the fact to OMB, Congress or auditors. Cost transfers can be between funds, budget activities, or projects. Because of the BIL's unique requirements for transparency and because of the multiple levels of review for BIL obligations and expenses, cost transfers initiated by regions are strongly discouraged. No cost transfers may be initiated without prior approval from the OCFO Zonal RWA/Capital Projects Director with the concurrence of BBP. Regions shall request cost transfers between the FBF (192X) and the BIL fund (192J) only when the original obligation is clearly in error, or when the identified scope is clearly miscoded. Likewise, regions will request cost transfers between Budget Activities within 192J only when the original obligation is in error. 9 DocuSign Envelope ID: 7808D437-0B9B-42AF-9024-32EF79B4FA5A All requests for cost transfers must be submitted by the zonal OCFO capital projects budget analyst and must be submitted to the OCFO Zonal RWA/Capital ProjectsDirector for concurrence, and finally to the BBP Capital Projects team for review and concurrence. This process is for approval only. Once the request is approved, the region must transfer the costs by following normal procedures. F. Property In addition to the PBS Property Accounting Handbook, the following guidance is provided to address the specific changes that must be accomplished due to the BIL. 1. Establishing 192J Funded Projects Projects exceeding $50,000 from 192J funds must be assigned a capitalized Accounting System Identification (ASID) in PBS s Inventory Reporting Information System (IRIS), while projects under $50,000 must be assigned an expensed ASID. Because it is PBS  s policy to capitalize at the ASID level, only one ASID should be used even if the project is funded through 192X and 192J. If the ASID is funded by 192X and 192J, IRIS users need to indicate in the appropriate field that the project is multiple funded and select the corresponding Budget Activity. If a project is funded solely from 192J, the ASID number will be assigned based on the type of work conducted, similar to PBS s process under 192X. Each ASID number should tie back to the original project line item number (or LIN) and, while each project can have multiple ASIDs, there must only be one project line item number for each 192J funded project. New construction projects must continue to be assigned N- type ASIDs. These ASIDs will be funded from Budget Activities PG11 (CBP LPOE Five Year Plan Projects), PG12 (AJP Priority LPOE Projects), PG13 (LPOE Paving, Acquisition of Leased LPOE, and FMCSA Projects) and PG14 (Project Contingency). Should a region have a blended new construction/R&A project, please consult with zonal budget and BBP. Repair and Alteration (R&A) projects exceeding the current prospectus limit will continue to be assigned V-type ASIDs for construction and non-advanced design. Currently, there are no advanced design projects that should be assigned S-type ASIDs under 192J. All R&A projects under prospectus will be assigned R-type ASIDs. The spending plan will list the appropriate budget activities and ASID types to be recorded into IRIS for these projects. Traditionally, LPOE project are funded through new construction using N-type ASIDs; however, depending on the scope of the project, the project may need to be coded as a R&A project and could be funded from PG11-PG14 (if deemed necessary and approved by BBP and the Capital Assessment and Allocation Division (PTB)). Should there be any operating costs funded by BIL, ASIDs will not be required for PG15 (Operating Costs). 10 DocuSign Envelope ID: 7808D437-0B9B-42AF-9024-32EF79B4FA5A PG14 funds will be used as a source for additional project contingency through a stringent governance process managed by the PMO. Regions should plan to stay within the standard construction contingency for their projects, which is already part of the PG11, 12 and 13 project budgets as included in the spend plan. Regions will need approval from the PMO to receive a budget increase from the PG14 program contingency. If approved, funds will be allowed in PG14 and the contingency accounting string will need to be used on the project. Therefore, PG14 costs related to a specific construction project must cite the N, S, V, or R-type ASID for that project and use the same LIN. Fund type 192J: Budget Activity Line item type PG11 PG12 PG13 PG14 PG15 N, L, R N, L, R N, L, R N, L, R n/a ASID type N, V, R N, V, R N, V, R N, V, R R An IRIS National Priority Code is not needed for Fund 192J. IRIS now has the capability to assign ASIDs to the 192J funded budget activities. As previously discussed, IRIS users need to check the multiple fund indicator for the ASID with the appropriate Budget Activity Code in IRIS. For any environmental-related cleanup costs, a separate ASID with expensed accounting treatment will need to be established for any environmental work items. See Chief Financial Officer Manual, Volume 3, OCFO 4260.3 (May 23, 2019), Chapter 5: Expenses, Part 4 for more details. 2. Monitoring Capitalized Projects As PBS receives additional funding under 192J for existing projects, the capitalization status of projects may change since the scope of work and/or dollar amount may change. For example, if a project originally was expensed since it was primarily for repairs, but additional funding allows PBS to improve the asset beyond its original condition, it must be capitalized if it exceeds PBS s capitalization threshold of $50,000. The capitalization threshold is based on the ASID s delivered orders under both funds and under all budget activities. If a project's capitalization status changes, the Regional IRIS Power User must first adjust the work category code and send an email to PBS.Property@gsa.gov informing BGP of the change and reason. The BGP Property Team will then request financial system adjustments as needed. 11 DocuSign Envelope ID: 7808D437-0B9B-42AF-9024-32EF79B4FA5A Estimated Substantial Completion Date (ESCD): The ESCD is the planned date for the asset to be ready for its intended purpose, regardless of funding code. The estimated SCD should be updated and maintained in IRIS throughout the life of the project. If the scope of work will change due to additional 192J funds, regional associates should adjust the date as soon as a date is established. Additionally, study, design, and construction award dates should also be entered as incurred to ensure IRIS reflects the proper project status. Actual Substantial Completion Date (ASCD): The ASCD is the actual date the asset can be operated or occupied, even though minor repairs or construction may be needed. It is the date when PBS inspects, approves and determines that work has been performed to bring the project to the degree of completion that is necessary for the asset to be used for its intended purpose. Associated construction or physical, or financial completion dates, that are associated with the project shall not delay reporting of the ASCD. Depreciation: Once the project reaches substantial completion and the ASCD is entered into IRIS, project costs will transfer from the construction-in-process to the completed buildings accounts and depreciation will be recorded. The useful lives of projects, which are based on project type, will remain unchanged, regardless if funded completely or partly under fund 192J. For additional information related to Property, please contact Claudine Schleicher at 202-821-8342 or Amber Cochran at 202-236-7258. G. RWA Tracking The following guidance applies to RWA acceptance and processing for RWAs that support GSAs BIL projects, specifically RWAs from U.S. Customs and Border Protection (CBP) for Furniture, Fixtures, and Equipment. Intake Process: Regions will follow standard PBS RWA policy (Reimbursable Work Authorizations National Policy Manual, PBS 1000.2B (August 1, 2020), as revised). In addition, BIL LPOE RWAs must be approved by the LPOE PMO before accepted by PBS. The LPOE PMO will maintain a list of projected CBP RWAs funded with CBP BIL funding. Note: CBP RWAs funded with BIL funding will contain the following TAS, which indicates the RWA is funded from BIL: 070 2022 2026 0530000 *070 is connected to CBP agency bureau code, then the year of the appropriation and the year of expiration of obligational authority. 0530 is an identifier for O&S projects (CBP s BIL projects) 12 DocuSign Envelope ID: 7808D437-0B9B-42AF-9024-32EF79B4FA5A Reminder: Any B-type RWAs must be associated with a Project Control Number and ASID code connecting it to the GSA-funded portion of the work (usually V-type or N- type). In addition, the associated PCN must be entered in the PCN field in RETA (see screenshot below). For additional assistance please contact your RWA financial point of contact. H. PBS Systems The following PBS systems have been modified to include the new fund 192J financial activity: a. Kahua b. Capital Projects Application (CPA) c. Business Intelligence/Business Objects d. RETA e. Inventory Reporting Information System (IRIS) 13 DocuSign Envelope ID: 7808D437-0B9B-42AF-9024-32EF79B4FA5A f. REXUS g. ULO database Because these systems rely heavily on templates, not every system can accept every possible combination of fund code, budget activity code, organization code, and project code. If you have trouble entering obligations or other transactions, please first check to be sure that you have made no errors, then contact your local budget analyst for further assistance. I. FY 2022 and Beyond $3.418 billion in BIL funding is available for FY22 and beyond as no-year funding. Beginning with the FY2024 Budget Call, OCFO will start estimating impacts to budgets as a result of any completed BIL projects. For example, utilities, cleaning, and maintenance costs will need to be budgeted in the appropriate fiscal year for any new LPOEs or completed projects coming online. 14 DocuSign Envelope ID: 7808D437-0B9B-42AF-9024-32EF79B4FA5A

results.EO_Text: Federal Register / Vol. 90, No. 19 / Thursday, January 30, 2025 / Presidential Documents 8615 Presidential Documents Executive Order 14168 of January 20, 2025 Defending Women From Gender Ideology Extremism and Re- storing Biological Truth to the Federal Government By the authority vested in me as President by the Constitution and the laws of the United States of America, including section 7301 of title 5, United States Code, it is hereby ordered: Section 1. Purpose. Across the country, ideologues who deny the biological reality of sex have increasingly used legal and other socially coercive means to permit men to self-identify as women and gain access to intimate single- sex spaces and activities designed for women, from women s domestic abuse shelters to women s workplace showers. This is wrong. Efforts to eradicate the biological reality of sex fundamentally attack women by depriving them of their dignity, safety, and well-being. The erasure of sex in language and policy has a corrosive impact not just on women but on the validity of the entire American system. Basing Federal policy on truth is critical to scientific inquiry, public safety, morale, and trust in government itself. This unhealthy road is paved by an ongoing and purposeful attack against the ordinary and longstanding use and understanding of biological and scientific terms, replacing the immutable biological reality of sex with an internal, fluid, and subjective sense of self unmoored from biological facts. Invalidating the true and biological category of  woman  improperly trans- forms laws and policies designed to protect sex-based opportunities into laws and policies that undermine them, replacing longstanding, cherished legal rights and values with an identity-based, inchoate social concept. Accordingly, my Administration will defend women s rights and protect freedom of conscience by using clear and accurate language and policies that recognize women are biologically female, and men are biologically male. Sec. 2. Policy and Definitions. It is the policy of the United States to recognize two sexes, male and female. These sexes are not changeable and are grounded in fundamental and incontrovertible reality. Under my direc- tion, the Executive Branch will enforce all sex-protective laws to promote this reality, and the following definitions shall govern all Executive interpre- tation of and application of Federal law and administration policy: (a)  Sex  shall refer to an individual s immutable biological classification as either male or female.  Sex  is not a synonym for and does not include the concept of  gender identity.  (b)  Women  or  woman  and  girls  or  girl  shall mean adult and juvenile human females, respectively. (c)  Men  or  man  and  boys  or  boy  shall mean adult and juvenile human males, respectively. (d)  Female  means a person belonging, at conception, to the sex that produces the large reproductive cell. (e)  Male  means a person belonging, at conception, to the sex that pro- duces the small reproductive cell. (f)  Gender ideology  replaces the biological category of sex with an ever-shifting concept of self-assessed gender identity, permitting the false claim that males can identify as and thus become women and vice versa, and requiring all institutions of society to regard this false claim as true. VerDate Sep<11>2014 18:43 Jan 29, 2025 Jkt 265001 PO 00000 Frm 00001 Fmt 4790 Sfmt 4790 E:\FR\FM\30JAE7.SGM 30JAE7 3 1 C O D Z E R P _ R F h t i w D O R P 3 2 N Q X 1 1 K S D n o r e t t o l 8616 Federal Register / Vol. 90, No. 19 / Thursday, January 30, 2025 / Presidential Documents Gender ideology includes the idea that there is a vast spectrum of genders that are disconnected from one s sex. Gender ideology is internally incon- sistent, in that it diminishes sex as an identifiable or useful category but nevertheless maintains that it is possible for a person to be born in the wrong sexed body. (g)  Gender identity  reflects a fully internal and subjective sense of self, disconnected from biological reality and sex and existing on an infinite continuum, that does not provide a meaningful basis for identification and cannot be recognized as a replacement for sex. Sec. 3. Recognizing Women Are Biologically Distinct From Men. (a) Within 30 days of the date of this order, the Secretary of Health and Human Services shall provide to the U.S. Government, external partners, and the public clear guidance expanding on the sex-based definitions set forth in this order. (b) Each agency and all Federal employees shall enforce laws governing sex-based rights, protections, opportunities, and accommodations to protect men and women as biologically distinct sexes. Each agency should therefore give the terms  sex ,  male ,  female ,  men ,  women ,  boys  and  girls  the meanings set forth in section 2 of this order when interpreting or applying statutes, regulations, or guidance and in all other official agency business, documents, and communications. (c) When administering or enforcing sex-based distinctions, every agency and all Federal employees acting in an official capacity on behalf of their agency shall use the term  sex  and not  gender  in all applicable Federal policies and documents. (d) The Secretaries of State and Homeland Security, and the Director of the Office of Personnel Management, shall implement changes to require that government-issued identification documents, including passports, visas, and Global Entry cards, accurately reflect the holder s sex, as defined under section 2 of this order; and the Director of the Office of Personnel Manage- ment shall ensure that applicable personnel records accurately report Federal employees  sex, as defined by section 2 of this order. (e) Agencies shall remove all statements, policies, regulations, forms, com- munications, or other internal and external messages that promote or other- wise inculcate gender ideology, and shall cease issuing such statements, policies, regulations, forms, communications or other messages. Agency forms that require an individual s sex shall list male or female, and shall not request gender identity. Agencies shall take all necessary steps, as permitted by law, to end the Federal funding of gender ideology. (f) The prior Administration argued that the Supreme Court s decision in Bostock v. Clayton County (2020), which addressed Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964, requires gender identity-based access to single- sex spaces under, for example, Title IX of the Educational Amendments Act. This position is legally untenable and has harmed women. The Attorney General shall therefore immediately issue guidance to agencies to correct the misapplication of the Supreme Court s decision in Bostock v. Clayton County (2020) to sex-based distinctions in agency activities. In addition, the Attorney General shall issue guidance and assist agencies in protecting sex-based distinctions, which are explicitly permitted under Constitutional and statutory precedent. (g) Federal funds shall not be used to promote gender ideology. Each agency shall assess grant conditions and grantee preferences and ensure grant funds do not promote gender ideology. Sec. 4. Privacy in Intimate Spaces. (a) The Attorney General and Secretary of Homeland Security shall ensure that males are not detained in women s prisons or housed in women s detention centers, including through amend- ment, as necessary, of Part 115.41 of title 28, Code of Federal Regulations and interpretation guidance regarding the Americans with Disabilities Act. VerDate Sep<11>2014 18:43 Jan 29, 2025 Jkt 265001 PO 00000 Frm 00002 Fmt 4790 Sfmt 4790 E:\FR\FM\30JAE7.SGM 30JAE7 3 1 C O D Z E R P _ R F h t i w D O R P 3 2 N Q X 1 1 K S D n o r e t t o l Federal Register / Vol. 90, No. 19 / Thursday, January 30, 2025 / Presidential Documents 8617 (b) The Secretary of Housing and Urban Development shall prepare and submit for notice and comment rulemaking a policy to rescind the final rule entitled  Equal Access in Accordance with an Individual s Gender Identity in Community Planning and Development Programs  of September 21, 2016, 81 FR 64763, and shall submit for public comment a policy protecting women seeking single-sex rape shelters. (c) The Attorney General shall ensure that the Bureau of Prisons revises its policies concerning medical care to be consistent with this order, and shall ensure that no Federal funds are expended for any medical procedure, treatment, or drug for the purpose of conforming an inmate s appearance to that of the opposite sex. (d) Agencies shall effectuate this policy by taking appropriate action to ensure that intimate spaces designated for women, girls, or females (or for men, boys, or males) are designated by sex and not identity. Sec. 5. Protecting Rights. The Attorney General shall issue guidance to ensure the freedom to express the binary nature of sex and the right to single-sex spaces in workplaces and federally funded entities covered by the Civil Rights Act of 1964. In accordance with that guidance, the Attorney General, the Secretary of Labor, the General Counsel and Chair of the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission, and each other agency head with enforcement responsibilities under the Civil Rights Act shall prioritize inves- tigations and litigation to enforce the rights and freedoms identified. Sec. 6. Bill Text. Within 30 days of the date of this order, the Assistant to the President for Legislative Affairs shall present to the President proposed bill text to codify the definitions in this order. Sec. 7. Agency Implementation and Reporting. (a) Within 120 days of the date of this order, each agency head shall submit an update on implementa- tion of this order to the President, through the Director of the Office of Management and Budget. That update shall address: (i) changes to agency documents, including regulations, guidance, forms, and communications, made to comply with this order; and (ii) agency-imposed requirements on federally funded entities, including contractors, to achieve the policy of this order. (b) The requirements of this order supersede conflicting provisions in any previous Executive Orders or Presidential Memoranda, including but not limited to Executive Orders 13988 of January 20, 2021, 14004 of January 25, 2021, 14020 and 14021 of March 8, 2021, and 14075 of June 15, 2022. These Executive Orders are hereby rescinded, and the White House Gender Policy Council established by Executive Order 14020 is dissolved. (c) Each agency head shall promptly rescind all guidance documents incon- sistent with the requirements of this order or the Attorney General s guidance issued pursuant to this order, or rescind such parts of such documents that are inconsistent in such manner. Such documents include, but are not limited to: (i)  The White House Toolkit on Transgender Equality ; (ii) the Department of Education s guidance documents including: (A)  2024 Title IX Regulations: Pointers for Implementation  (July 2024); (B)  U.S. Department of Education Toolkit: Creating Inclusive and Non- discriminatory School Environments for LGBTQI+ Students ; (C)  U.S. Department of Education Supporting LGBTQI+ Youth and Families in School  (June 21, 2023); (D)  Departamento de Educacio  n de EE.UU. Apoyar a los jo  venes y familias LGBTQI+ en la escuela  (June 21, 2023); (E)  Supporting Intersex Students: A Resource for Students, Families, and Educators  (October 2021); (F)  Supporting Transgender Youth in School  (June 2021); VerDate Sep<11>2014 18:43 Jan 29, 2025 Jkt 265001 PO 00000 Frm 00003 Fmt 4790 Sfmt 4790 E:\FR\FM\30JAE7.SGM 30JAE7 3 1 C O D Z E R P _ R F h t i w D O R P 3 2 N Q X 1 1 K S D n o r e t t o l 8618 Federal Register / Vol. 90, No. 19 / Thursday, January 30, 2025 / Presidential Documents (G)  Letter to Educators on Title IX s 49th Anniversary  (June 23, 2021); (H)  Confronting Anti-LGBTQI+ Harassment in Schools: A Resource for Students and Families  (June 2021); (I)  Enforcement of Title IX of the Education Amendments of 1972 With Respect to Discrimination Based on Sexual Orientation and Gender Identity in Light of Bostock v. Clayton County  (June 22, 2021); (J)  Education in a Pandemic: The Disparate Impacts of COVID 19 on America s Students  (June 9, 2021); and (K)  Back-to-School Message for Transgender Students from the U.S. Depts of Justice, Education, and HHS  (Aug. 17, 2021); (iii) the Attorney General s Memorandum of March 26, 2021 entitled  Ap- plication of Bostock v. Clayton County to Title IX of the Education Amend- ments of 1972 ; and (iv) the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission s  Enforcement Guid- ance on Harassment in the Workplace  (April 29, 2024). Sec. 8. General Provisions. (a) Nothing in this order shall be construed to impair or otherwise affect: (i) the authority granted by law to an executive department or agency, or the head thereof; or (ii) the functions of the Director of the Office of Management and Budget relating to budgetary, administrative, or legislative proposals. (b) This order shall be implemented consistent with applicable law and subject to the availability of appropriations. (c) This order is not intended to, and does not, create any right or benefit, substantive or procedural, enforceable at law or in equity by any party against the United States, its departments, agencies, or entities, its officers, employees, or agents, or any other person. Policy Analysis Summary:

1. Policy Text Summary:
The document is a GSA memorandum providing financial guidance for implementing the Infrastructure Investment and Jobs Act (IIJA), specifically focusing on funding for land ports of entry (LPOE) projects. The policy establishes new accounting codes, tracking requirements, and financial management protocols for $3.418 billion in infrastructure funding.

2. Executive Order Text Summary:
The executive order focuses on defining biological sex, restricting gender identity considerations in federal policies, and mandating agencies to use strict biological definitions in documentation, funding, and practices.

3. Applicability Analysis:
The executive order does NOT directly impact the financial management policy for the Infrastructure Investment and Jobs Act. This policy is a purely financial and administrative guidance document dealing with budget tracking, accounting codes, and project management for infrastructure projects. The executive order's provisions around gender definitions and policies do not intersect with the technical financial procedures outlined in this GSA memorandum.

4. Compliance Next Steps:
No immediate compliance actions are required for this specific policy document. The financial guidance remains valid and unchanged by the executive order.

Potential Indirect Considerations:
- Future GSA policies or communications might need review to ensure alignment with the executive order's language requirements
- Grant conditions and documentation may require careful review in future iterations

Recommendation:
Continue implementing the existing financial guidance for the Infrastructure Investment and Jobs Act as originally outlined. Consult with GSA legal counsel for any broader organizational policy reviews triggered by the executive order.
results.updated_summary: The Infrastructure Investment and Jobs Act financial guidance is a technical, purely financial policy focused on budget tracking and project management for infrastructure projects. The executive order on gender ideology is a broad policy directive about language and definitions, which does not substantively impact the financial and administrative procedures outlined in the GSA memorandum.
results.phase1_response:
## Policy Analysis Summary

### 1. Brief Summary of Policy Text
The GSA memorandum from September 28, 2022, provides financial execution guidance for the $3.4 billion appropriated to the Federal Buildings Fund under the Infrastructure Investment and Jobs Act (Bipartisan Infrastructure Law). The policy establishes new tracking requirements for program support costs, including specific accounting codes, labor coding procedures for administrative hours, and timecarding requirements for PBS employees working on BIL-related activities.

### 2. Brief Summary of Executive Order Text
Executive Order 14168, signed January 20, 2025, titled "Defending Women From Gender Ideology Extremism and Restoring Biological Truth to the Federal Government," directs federal agencies to use language and policies that recognize biological sex distinctions. The order specifically defines women as "biologically female" and men as "biologically male," rejecting gender self-identification policies that allow access to single-sex spaces and activities based on gender identity rather than biological sex.

### 3. Detailed Explanation of Executive Order Applicability
This executive order **does not apply** to the GSA policy document for the following reasons:

- **Subject Matter Scope**: The GSA memorandum is purely focused on financial tracking, accounting procedures, and budget execution for infrastructure projects. It contains no language, policies, or provisions related to gender, sex, single-sex facilities, or gender identity issues.

- **Operational Focus**: The policy addresses administrative and financial processes such as tracking codes, timecarding procedures, fund allocation, and accounting strings. These technical financial management procedures are unrelated to the gender ideology and biological sex recognition issues addressed in the executive order.

- **No Relevant Content**: After reviewing the available portions of the GSA memorandum, there are no references to facilities design, restroom policies, workplace accommodations, or any other areas where gender/sex distinctions would be relevant to the executive order's requirements.

- **Different Policy Domains**: The executive order targets policies that involve sex-based classifications, single-sex spaces, and gender identity accommodations, while the GSA policy operates in the financial management and accounting domain.

### 4. Next Steps for Compliance
No compliance actions are required because the executive order does not apply to this policy. The GSA memorandum can continue to be implemented as written without modification related to Executive Order 14168.

**Final Determination: [Not Affected]**

results.phase2_response:
**Step 1: Policy Domain/Subject Area**
The policy focuses on federal building infrastructure funding and financial administration. Specifically, it provides guidance for the General Services Administration's Public Buildings Service on tracking and accounting for $3.4 billion in Infrastructure Investment and Jobs Act appropriations to the Federal Buildings Fund, including establishing specific accounting codes and tracking requirements.

**Step 2: Executive Order Domain/Subject Area**
The executive order addresses gender ideology and biological sex definitions in federal policy. It focuses on preventing individuals from self-identifying as a different biological sex to access single-sex spaces and activities, particularly protecting women's spaces like domestic abuse shelters and workplace facilities.

**Step 3: Domain Comparison and Impact Assessment**
These domains are fundamentally different - one deals with infrastructure finance and accounting, the other with gender policy and facility access rights. However, there is a potential intersection point: federal buildings managed by GSA may contain single-sex facilities (restrooms, locker rooms, etc.) that could be affected by the executive order's requirements regarding biological sex definitions.

**Step 4: Independent Assessment Considering Context**
While the phase1_flag indicates "Not Affected," I must consider whether the executive order could impact how federal buildings funded through this infrastructure guidance are designed, configured, or operated regarding single-sex facilities.

**Final Decision: [Not Affected]**

**Full Justification:**

1. **Policy Domain**: Federal building infrastructure funding, financial tracking, and accounting procedures for GSA's Federal Buildings Fund under the Infrastructure Investment and Jobs Act.

2. **Executive Order Domain**: Gender ideology restrictions, biological sex definitions, and access to single-sex spaces and facilities across federal operations.

3. **Impact Analysis**: While both involve federal facilities, the connection is indirect and speculative. The policy is purely administrative, focused on financial tracking mechanisms (accounting codes, fund management) rather than facility design, operations, or access policies. The executive order, while it may eventually affect how federal buildings operate regarding single-sex facilities, does not directly impact the financial guidance and tracking requirements established in this memorandum.

4. **Key Language Supporting Determination**: The policy text is entirely procedural, stating "PBS must use tracking code Y0000BIL in the accounting string for non-labor program requirements using 192X funding." There are no provisions related to facility design, user access, or operational policies that would be directly affected by gender ideology restrictions.

5. **Nuances Considered**: Although GSA manages federal buildings that may contain single-sex facilities, this particular policy document addresses only the financial and accounting aspects of infrastructure funding. Any impact from the executive order would more likely affect separate GSA operational policies or building management directives, not this specific financial guidance memorandum. The connection is too attenuated and speculative to constitute a direct or meaningful indirect impact on the policy's core financial tracking requirements.

Key Differences:

While the SME's justification is more succinct, the model's expanded reasoning demonstrates thorough understanding of why these policies operate in essentially separate spheres. The model's systematic approach to impact analysis strengthens rather than contradicts the SME's reasoning.

results.Policy_Title: Strategic Direction on Lease Terms During and Following the COVID-19 Pandemic
results.Policy Text: GSA Public Buildings Service May 7, 2021 MEMORANDUM FOR: PBS REGIONAL COMMISSIONERS PBS REGIONAL LEASING DIRECTORS PBS REGIONAL LEASE ACQUISITION OFFICERS PBS REGIONAL PORTFOLIO DIRECTORS FROM: JOHN D. THOMAS ACTING ASSISTANT COMMISSIONER OFFICE OF LEASING (PR) STUART BURNS ASSISTANT COMMISSIONER OFFICE OF PORTFOLIO MANAGEMENT AND CUSTOMER ENGAGEMENT (PT) Subject: LEASING ALERT (LA-21-06) - Strategic Direction on Lease Terms During and Following the COVID-19 Pandemic This memorandum issues enhanced guidance to PBS offices engaged in planning, negotiating and awarding U.S. General Services Administration (GSA) leases during the COVID-19 pandemic. This guidance is intended to provide high level guidance on setting lease terms requirements during and following the COVID-19 pandemic and are considering expanding telework. This guidance is in addition to the Leasing Alert issued April 20, 2016 entitled Lease Term Strategy. In March 2020, because of the onset of the COVID-19 pandemic, much of the Federal Government moved to a mandatory, full-time telework status. Because the Government is still largely in a full-time telework status, many agencies are unsure of their future space requirements. GSA is concerned about a potential surge in short term lease extensions. These short term extensions would result in an anticipated increased cost to the taxpayers, and an associated best manage its workload. U.S. General Services Administration 1800 F Street, NW Washington, DC 20405-0002 www.gsa.gov Therefore, in response to the uncertainty of - term space needs and the potential vacancy risk, GSA is adjusting its suggested approach when determining the length of lease terms. First, GSA must continue to consider how a particular lease transaction aligns with the portfolio strategies of the local market and the customer agency and the degree of financial risk the Public Buildings Service (PBS) is prepared to assume when entering into leases on behalf of a customer agency. Second, the following lease term strategies should be considered: For agencies that submit their long term lease requirements, longer term leases (greater than 10 years) should be considered particularly when the agency requires a specialized facility, to perform their mission critical work (e.g., the judiciary, federal inspection agencies operating at land ports of entry, law enforcement components and those agencies using laboratory spaces). For agencies that submit their short term lease requirements but are still determining their long term space requirements, short term leases (4-6 years) should be considered. This 4-6 year term will allow agencies time to finalize their long term space requirements, while providing GSA time to procure and build out the space. Page 2 of 2
results.EO_Text: Federal Register / Vol. 90, No. 71 / Tuesday, April 15, 2025 / Presidential Documents 15629 Presidential Documents Executive Order 14267 of April 9, 2025 Reducing Anti-Competitive Regulatory Barriers By the authority vested in me as President by the Constitution and the laws of the United States of America, it is hereby ordered: Section 1. Purpose. Federal regulations should not predetermine economic winners and losers. Yet some regulations operate to exclude new market entrants. Regulations that reduce competition, entrepreneurship, and innova- tion as well as the benefits they create for American consumers should be eliminated. This order commences the process for eliminating anti-com- petitive regulations to revitalize the American economy. Sec. 2. Definitions. (a)  Agency  has the meaning given to it in section 3502 of title 44, United States Code, except that it does not include the Executive Office of the President or any components thereof. (b)  Agency head  means the highest-ranking official of an agency, such as the Secretary, Administrator, Chairman, or Director, unless otherwise specified in this order. Sec. 3. Rescinding Anti-Competitive Regulations. (a) Agency heads shall, in consultation with the Chairman of the Federal Trade Commission (Chair- man) and the Attorney General, complete a review of all regulations subject to their rulemaking authority and identify those that: (i) create, or facilitate the creation of, de facto or de jure monopolies; (ii) create unnecessary barriers to entry for new market participants; (iii) limit competition between competing entities or have the effect of limiting competition between competing entities; (iv) create or facilitate licensure or accreditation requirements that unduly limit competition; (v) unnecessarily burden the agency s procurement processes, thereby lim- iting companies  ability to compete for procurements; or (vi) otherwise impose anti-competitive restraints or distortions on the oper- ation of the free market. (b) Within 70 days of the date of this order, agency heads shall each provide to the Chairman and the Attorney General a list of regulations identified by the categories specified in subsection (a) of this section. Agency heads shall also include a recommendation as to whether each of the listed regulations warrants rescission or modification in light of its anti-competitive effects. For recommended modifications, agency heads shall briefly specify what modification is appropriate. For regulations that are anti-competitive by design, agency heads shall provide a justification for their anti-competitive effects if the agency head is not proposing rescission or modification. (c) In conducting the review required by subsection (a) of this section, agency heads shall prioritize review of those rules that satisfy the definition of  significant regulatory action  in Executive Order 12866 of September 30, 1993 (Regulatory Planning and Review), as amended. (d) Within 10 days of the date of this order, the Chairman shall issue a request for information (RFI) that seeks public input on the identification of regulations that fall within the categories specified in subsection (a) of this section, as well as comments explaining the proposed classifications. The request shall remain open for 40 days. Upon the close of the RFI VerDate Sep<11>2014 16:28 Apr 14, 2025 Jkt 265001 PO 00000 Frm 00001 Fmt 4790 Sfmt 4790 E:\FR\FM\15APE4.SGM 15APE4 4 C O D Z E R P _ R F h t i w D O R P 3 2 N Q X 1 1 K S D n o r e t t o l 15630 Federal Register / Vol. 90, No. 71 / Tuesday, April 15, 2025 / Presidential Documents period, the Chairman shall convey any relevant responses to the agency with rulemaking authority over the identified regulation. (e) Within 90 days of receipt of the agency lists specified in subsection (b) of this section, the Chairman, in consultation with the Attorney General, the Assistant to the President for Economic Policy, and the relevant agency heads, shall provide to the Director of the Office of Management and Budget (OMB Director) a consolidated list of regulations that warrant rescission or modification in light of their anti-competitive effects, along with rec- ommended modifications. The Chairman may include on the consolidated list regulations not originally included on an agency list if such regulations fall within at least one of the categories outlined in subsections (a)(i)  (vi) of this section. (f) Upon receipt of the consolidated list described in subsection (e) of this section, the OMB Director, through the Administrator of the Office of Information and Regulatory Affairs, shall consult with the Chairman, the Attorney General, the Assistant to the President for Economic Policy, and the relevant agency heads to decide whether to incorporate the proposed rescissions or modifications into the Unified Regulatory Agenda developed pursuant to Executive Order 14219 of February 19, 2025 (Ensuring Lawful Governance and Implementing the President s  Department of Government Efficiency  Deregulatory Initiative). Sec. 4. General Provisions. ## Policy Analysis: Impact of Executive Order 14267 on GSA Leasing Alert LA-21-06

### 1. Brief Summary of the Policy Text

GSA Leasing Alert LA-21-06, issued May 7, 2021, provides guidance to PBS offices on lease term requirements during and following the COVID-19 pandemic. The policy addresses concerns about potential short-term lease extensions due to agencies' uncertainty about future space needs while operating under expanded telework arrangements. The guidance aims to help GSA avoid increased costs to taxpayers and manage workload effectively by adjusting the approach to determining lease term lengths, considering portfolio strategies, customer agency needs, and financial risk management.

### 2. Brief Summary of the Executive Order Text

Executive Order 14267, signed April 9, 2025, directs federal agencies to eliminate anti-competitive regulations that create barriers to market competition. The order requires agency heads to review all regulations under their authority and identify those that: create monopolies, establish unnecessary barriers to entry, limit competition between entities, create burdensome licensure requirements, unnecessarily burden procurement processes, or impose other anti-competitive restraints on free market operations.

### 3. Detailed Explanation of Executive Order Applicability

This executive order **does apply** to the GSA leasing policy for the following reasons:

**Procurement Process Impact**: The leasing guidance directly affects GSA's procurement processes by establishing criteria for lease term determinations. Under section 3(a)(v) of the executive order, regulations that "unnecessarily burden the agency's procurement processes, thereby limiting companies' ability to compete for procurements" must be reviewed.

**Potential Competitive Barriers**: The policy's emphasis on avoiding short-term lease extensions and preference for certain lease term lengths could potentially:
- Limit opportunities for smaller or newer property management companies who might be more flexible with shorter terms
- Create barriers for property owners who prefer shorter lease arrangements
- Reduce competitive bidding opportunities if lease terms become too standardized

**Market Participant Access**: The guidance's focus on portfolio strategies and financial risk management could inadvertently create barriers to entry for new market participants in the federal leasing sector.

### 4. Next Steps to Achieve Compliance

To ensure compliance with Executive Order 14267, GSA should:

1. **Conduct Comprehensive Review**: Analyze LA-21-06 alongside all other leasing policies to identify provisions that may limit competition or create barriers to market entry.

2. **Stakeholder Consultation**: Engage with the Federal Trade Commission Chairman and Attorney General as required, plus industry stakeholders including property owners, real estate developers, and leasing companies of various sizes.

3. **Market Impact Assessment**: Evaluate whether the lease term guidance has created unintended competitive disadvantages for certain types of property providers or limited market participation.

4. **Policy Revision**: Modify the guidance to ensure maximum competitive opportunities while maintaining cost-effectiveness and operational efficiency. This may include:
   - Expanding flexibility in lease term options
   - Ensuring procurement processes don't favor established players
   - Removing any unnecessary barriers to participation by new market entrants

5. **Implementation Timeline**: Establish a clear timeline for policy review and revision consistent with the executive order's requirements.

**Final Determination: [Affected]**

results.EO_Text: Federal Register / Vol. 90, No. 46 / Tuesday, March 11, 2025 / Presidential Documents 11789 Presidential Documents Executive Order 14233 of March 6, 2025 Establishment of the Strategic Bitcoin Reserve and United States Digital Asset Stockpile By the authority vested in me as President by the Constitution and the laws of the United States of America, it is hereby ordered: Section 1. Background. Bitcoin is the original cryptocurrency. The Bitcoin protocol permanently caps the total supply of bitcoin (BTC) at 21 million coins, and has never been hacked. As a result of its scarcity and security, Bitcoin is often referred to as  digital gold . Because there is a fixed supply of BTC, there is a strategic advantage to being among the first nations to create a strategic bitcoin reserve. The United States Government currently holds a significant amount of BTC, but has not implemented a policy to maximize BTC s strategic position as a unique store of value in the global financial system. Just as it is in our country s interest to thoughtfully manage national ownership and control of any other resource, our Nation must harness, not limit, the power of digital assets for our prosperity. Sec. 2. Policy. It is the policy of the United States to establish a Strategic Bitcoin Reserve. It is further the policy of the United States to establish a United States Digital Asset Stockpile that can serve as a secure account for orderly and strategic management of the United States  other digital asset holdings. Sec. 3. Creation and Administration of the Strategic Bitcoin Reserve and United States Digital Asset Stockpile. (a) The Secretary of the Treasury shall establish an office to administer and maintain control of custodial accounts collectively known as the  Stra- tegic Bitcoin Reserve,  capitalized with all BTC held by the Department of the Treasury that was finally forfeited as part of criminal or civil asset forfeiture proceedings or in satisfaction of any civil money penalty imposed by any executive department or agency (agency) and that is not needed to satisfy requirements under 31 U.S.C. 9705 or released pursuant to sub- section (d) of this section (Government BTC). Within 30 days of the date of this order, each agency shall review its authorities to transfer any Govern- ment BTC held by it to the Strategic Bitcoin Reserve and shall submit a report reflecting the result of that review to the Secretary of the Treasury. Government BTC deposited into the Strategic Bitcoin Reserve shall not be sold and shall be maintained as reserve assets of the United States utilized to meet governmental objectives in accordance with applicable law. (b) The Secretary of the Treasury shall establish an office to administer and maintain control of custodial accounts collectively known as the  United States Digital Asset Stockpile,  capitalized with all digital assets owned by the Department of the Treasury, other than BTC, that were finally forfeited as part of criminal or civil asset forfeiture proceedings and that are not needed to satisfy requirements under 31 U.S.C. 9705 or released pursuant to subsection (d) of this section (Stockpile Assets). Within 30 days of the date of this order, each agency shall review its authorities to transfer any Stockpile Assets held by it to the United States Digital Asset Stockpile and shall submit a report reflecting the result of that review to the Secretary of the Treasury. The Secretary of the Treasury shall determine strategies for responsible stewardship of the United States Digital Asset Stockpile in accordance with applicable law. VerDate Sep<11>2014 17:24 Mar 10, 2025 Jkt 265001 PO 00000 Frm 00001 Fmt 4790 Sfmt 4790 E:\FR\FM\11MRE3.SGM 11MRE3 6 C O D Z E R P _ R F h t i w D O R P 3 2 N Q X 1 1 K S D n o r e t t o l 11790 Federal Register / Vol. 90, No. 46 / Tuesday, March 11, 2025 / Presidential Documents (c) The Secretary of the Treasury and the Secretary of Commerce shall develop strategies for acquiring additional Government BTC provided that such strategies are budget neutral and do not impose incremental costs on United States taxpayers. However, the United States Government shall not acquire additional Stockpile Assets other than in connection with crimi- nal or civil asset forfeiture proceedings or in satisfaction of any civil money penalty imposed by any agency without further executive or legislative action. (d)  Government Digital Assets  means all Government BTC and all Stock- pile Assets. The head of each agency shall not sell or otherwise dispose of any Government Digital Assets, except in connection with the Secretary of the Treasury s exercise of his lawful authority and responsible stewardship of the United States Digital Asset Stockpile pursuant to subsection (b) of this section, or pursuant to an order from a court of competent jurisdiction, as required by law, or in cases where the Attorney General or other relevant agency head determines that the Government Digital Assets (or the proceeds from the sale or disposition thereof) can and should: (i) be returned to identifiable and verifiable victims of crime; (ii) be used for law enforcement operations; (iii) be equitably shared with State and local law enforcement partners; or (iv) be released to satisfy requirements under 31 U.S.C. 9705, 28 U.S.C. 524(c), 18 U.S.C. 981, or 21 U.S.C. 881. (e) Within 60 days of the date of this order, the Secretary of the Treasury shall deliver an evaluation of the legal and investment considerations for establishing and managing the Strategic Bitcoin Reserve and United States Digital Asset Stockpile going forward, including the accounts in which the Strategic Bitcoin Reserve and United States Digital Asset Stockpile should be located and the need for any legislation to operationalize any aspect of this order or the proper management and administration of such accounts. Sec. 4. Accounting. Within 30 days of the date of this order, the head of each agency shall provide the Secretary of the Treasury and the President s Working Group on Digital Asset Markets with a full accounting of all Govern- ment Digital Assets in such agency s possession, including any information regarding the custodial accounts in which such Government Digital Assets are currently held that would be necessary to facilitate a transfer of the Government Digital Assets to the Strategic Bitcoin Reserve or the United States Digital Asset Stockpile. If such agency holds no Government Digital Assets, such agency shall confirm such fact to the Secretary of the Treasury and the President s Working Group on Digital Asset Markets within 30 days of the date of this order.
